text.text_translated:
Spider venom is found in most species. Its goal is to stun or kill the animals they catch, not to attack people.  

In fact, only twenty‑five of the known spider species make venom that can really harm humans. Although spider bites are painful, they are rarely deadly.  

The Sydney funnel‑web spider, a venomous spider that lives near Sydney, are famous because they can be dangerous. It has not caused any deaths since 1981. In that year, a special medicine called anti‑venom was created.  

However, be careful not to rub hairy spiders such as tarantulas the wrong way. When they feel danger they defend themselves by releasing a cloud of tiny hairs.  

These annoying hairs can get stuck in an attacker’s skin or eyes.
